intro: Dicrophyla, commonly known as the rock parsley, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate flowers. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often found in mountainous regions. The plant features finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, white or greenish-white flowers that bloom in clusters. Its root system is fibrous, and it is sometimes used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits. Dicrophyla is generally hardy and adaptable, thriving in temperate climates with well-drained soil.
